instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S0SW_LCD: What is PP3V3_S0SW_LCD? PP3V3_S0SW_LCD is a 3.3v power rail necessary to power the image circuitry on the screen. This is necessary to get a picture on the screen. .
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.BKLT_SCL: What is BKLT_SCL? BKLT_SCL is an I2C signal clock line between the LED driver that creates the LCD backlight power rail that powers the backlight in the screen and the screen. The screen needs to speak to the LED driver on this line before backlight voltage will be created..
definitions.LCDBKLT_EN_L: What is LCDBKLT_EN_L? This signal enables the backlight when it is low.  _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be low to enable backlight. .
definitions.BKLT_SD: What is BKLT_SD? BKLT_SD is a pin of the LED driver that goes to the voltage divider that feeds the gate of the transistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H and the backlight circuit. The LED driver will short this pin to ground when backlight circuit is ready to turn on. Prerequisites are 1) it is told to turn on via enable signal, the screen has communicated with the LED driver 2) current sensing circuit is working 3) does not detect an over-current situation such as the backlight power rail being shorted to ground.
definitions.I2C_BKLT: What is I2C_BKLT? I2C_BKLT is a data line between the LCD screen and the LED driver. This data line cannot short to ground. If it does, the screen cannot talk to the LED driver, and the LED driver will not allow the circuit to produce a backlight..
definitions.BKLT_EN_R: What is BKLT_EN_R? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. The “_R” suffix means that the signal is asserted when it is high, as in 3.3v, which is the opposite of the “_L”  suffix.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
i just work on this machine, no much experience with this model.

i can see the picture but no backlight

I bought a new display because i thought the problem is the backlight flex cable but same problem

so i measured the <SIGNAL>IPD_LID_OEPN</SIGNAL>, if closed has 0V if open has 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> has 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCD_BKLT</SIGNAL> is 0V

F8400 is ok and the area around <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> looks normaly

all the board is first time out of case and no liquid or similar to see

is this a known comon problem?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
when I start the machine and light a bright light on the screen i can see what happens. I see the apple logo and then the user account.
but now i saw that there is no touchbar activities. the tb should light up when comes up the user account isnt it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
Do you get correct <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>?
Also check voltage and diode mode on <SIGNAL>BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL>/SDA lines.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
still no progress in this case

<SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.35V and <RESISTOR>R8442</RESISTOR> is 0 Ohm
<SIGNAL>BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL>/SDA lines both have .529

external Display showing good
2 NEW Displays tested for working in other machine, working good, with this machine no backlight

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
so, if  <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCD_BKLT</SIGNAL> is 0V then 8400 is not switching on or  <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCD_BKLT</SIGNAL> is short to GND

in diode mode <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCD_BKLT</SIGNAL> to GND is .804

F8400 is ok

maybe <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL> is not working, how it is switching from <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> SD-Pin? should be Low if turned on isnt it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message: maybe <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL> is not working, how it is switching from <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> SD-Pin? should be Low if turned on isnt it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
<CHIP>U8400</CHIP> must pull down <SIGNAL>BKLT_SD</SIGNAL>.
But requires correct communication through <SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT</SIGNAL> bus; apart of high <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
checked now
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT_R</SIGNAL> is 12.93V, is ok in my opinion
<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL> is as well 12.93V should be zero i think?

ah ok, just read your post 2informaticos

so I checked <RESISTOR>R8450</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R8451</RESISTOR> both 0 Ohm
and <RESISTOR>R8452</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R8453</RESISTOR> both 1.8Ohm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
i disconnected the display and checked pin 26 and 24 on the flex cable
both 5.01V but on scope no communication to see may be because display is not connected

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message: LCD must be connected, if you look at image/backlight signals...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
ok. so i soldered now 2 cables on <CAPACITOR>C8553</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C8554</CAPACITOR> build in the board and signals are there
scl has a clock and sda has data signals

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
If these signals, as <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL>, arrive to <CHIP>U8400</CHIP>, you should have backlight.
If not, check all traces, solders and components around <CHIP>U8400</CHIP>.
